lines.value: marine mammals are aquatic mammals that rely on the ocean and other marine ecosystems for their existence
lines.name: English

lines.value: they include animals such as seals whales manatees sea otters and polar bears
lines.name: English

lines.value: they do not represent a distinct taxon or systematic grouping but rather have a polyphyletic relation due to convergent evolution as in they do not have an immediate common ancestor
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are also unified by their reliance on the marine environment for feeding
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammal adaptation to an aquatic lifestyle varies considerably between species
lines.name: English

lines.value: both cetaceans and sirenians are fully aquatic and therefore are obligate water dwellers
lines.name: English

lines.value: seals and sea lions are semiaquatic they spend the majority of their time in the water but need to return to land for important activities such as mating breeding and molting
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast both otters and the polar bear are much less adapted to aquatic living
lines.name: English

lines.value: their diet varies considerably as well some may eat zooplankton others may eat fish squid shellfish sea grass and a few may eat other mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the number of marine mammals is small compared to those found on land their roles in various ecosystems are large especially concerning the maintenance of marine ecosystems through processes including the regulation of prey populations
lines.name: English

lines.value: this role in maintaining ecosystems makes them of particular concern as 23% of marine mammal species are currently threatened
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals were first hunted by aboriginal peoples for food and other resources
lines.name: English

lines.value: many were also the target for commercial industry leading to a sharp decline in all populations of exploited species such as whales and seals
lines.name: English

lines.value: commercial hunting lead to the extinction of steller's sea cow and the caribbean monk seal
lines.name: English

lines.value: after commercial hunting ended some species such as the gray whale and northern elephant seal have rebounded in numbers conversely other species such as the north atlantic right whale are critically endangered
lines.name: English

lines.value: other than hunting marine mammals can be killed as bycatch from fisheries where they become entangled in fixed netting and drown or starve
lines.name: English

lines.value: increased ocean traffic causes collisions between fast ocean vessels and large marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: habitat degradation also threatens marine mammals and their ability to find and catch food
lines.name: English

lines.value: noise pollution for example may adversely affect echolocating mammals and the ongoing effects of global warming degrade arctic environments
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals form a diverse group of 129 species that rely on the ocean for their existence
lines.name: English

lines.value: they do not represent a distinct taxon or systematic grouping but instead have a polyphyletic relationship
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are also unified by their reliance on the marine environment for feeding
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite the diversity in morphology seen between groups improved foraging efficiency has been the main driver in their evolution
lines.name: English

lines.value: the level of dependence on the marine environment for existence varies considerably with species
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example dolphins and whales are completely dependent on the marine environment for all stages of their life seals feed in the ocean but breed on land and polar bears must feed on land
lines.name: English

lines.value: twenty three percent of marine mammal species are threatened.<ref name="ship"> the cetaceans became aquatic around 50 million years ago mya
lines.name: English

lines.value: based on molecular and morphological research the cetaceans genetically and morphologically fall firmly within the artiodactyla even-toed ungulates
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term cetartiodactyla reflects the idea that whales evolved within the ungulates
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term was coined by merging the name for the two orders cetacea and artiodactyla into a single word
lines.name: English

lines.value: under this definition the closest living land relative of the whales and dolphins is thought to be the hippopotamuses
lines.name: English

lines.value: sirenians the sea cows became aquatic around 40 million years ago
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first appearance of sirenians in the fossil record was during the early eocene and by the late eocene sirenians had significantly diversified
lines.name: English

lines.value: inhabitants of rivers estuaries and nearshore marine waters they were able to spread rapidly
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most primitive sirenian prorastomus was found in jamaica unlike other marine mammals which originated from the old world such as cetaceans ).
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first known quadrupedal sirenian was pezosiren from the early eocene
lines.name: English

lines.value: the earliest known sea cows of the families prorastomidae and protosirenidae were both confined to the eocene and were pig sized four legged amphibious creatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first members of dugongidae appeared by the end of the eocene
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this point sea cows were fully aquatic
lines.name: English

lines.value: pinnipeds split from other caniforms 50 mya during the eocene
lines.name: English

lines.value: their evolutionary link to terrestrial mammals was unknown until the 2007 discovery of puijila darwini in early miocene deposits in nunavut canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: like a modern otter puijila had a long tail short limbs and webbed feet instead of flippers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the lineages of otariidae eared seals and odobenidae walrus split almost 28 mya
lines.name: English

lines.value: phocids earless seals are known to have existed for at least 15 mya and molecular evidence supports a divergence of the monachinae monk seals and phocinae lineages 22 mya
lines.name: English

lines.value: fossil evidence indicates the sea otter enhydra lineage became isolated in the north pacific approximately two mya giving rise to the now extinct enhydra macrodonta and the modern sea otter enhydra lutris
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sea otter evolved initially in northern hokkaido and russia and then spread east to the aleutian islands mainland alaska and down the north american coast
lines.name: English

lines.value: in comparison to cetaceans sirenians and pinnipeds which entered the water approximately 50 40 and 20 mya respectively the sea otter is a relative newcomer to marine life
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some respects though the sea otter is more fully adapted to water than pinnipeds which must haul out on land or ice to give birth
lines.name: English

lines.value: polar bears are thought to have diverged from a population of brown bears ursus arctos that became isolated during a period of glaciation in the pleistocene or from the eastern part of siberia from kamchatka and the kolym peninsula
lines.name: English

lines.value: the oldest known polar bear fossil is a 130000 to 110000-year-old jaw bone found on prince charles foreland in 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mitochondrial dna mtdna of the polar bear diverged from the brown bear roughly 150000 years ago
lines.name: English

lines.value: further some clades of brown bear as assessed by their mtdna are more closely related to polar bears than to other brown bears meaning that the polar bear might not be considered a species under some species concepts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in general terrestrial amniote invasions of the sea have become more frequent in the cenozoic than they were in the mesozoic
lines.name: English

lines.value: factors contributing to this trend include the increasing productivity of near shore marine environments and the role of endothermy in facilitating this transition
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals are widely distributed throughout the globe but their distribution is patchy and coincides with the productivity of the oceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: species richness peaks at around 40 latitude both north and south
lines.name: English

lines.value: this corresponds to the highest levels of primary production around north and south america africa asia and australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: total species range is highly variable for marine mammal species
lines.name: English

lines.value: on average most marine mammals have ranges which are equivalent or smaller than one fifth of the indian ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: the variation observed in range size is a result of the different ecological requirements of each species and their ability to cope with a broad range of environmental conditions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the high degree of overlap between marine mammal species richness and areas of human impact on the environment is of concern
lines.name: English

lines.value: most marine mammals such as seals and sea otters inhabit the coast
lines.name: English

lines.value: seals however also use a number of terrestrial habitats both continental and island
lines.name: English

lines.value: in temperate and tropical areas they haul out on to sandy and pebble beaches rocky shores shoals mud flats tide pools and in sea caves
lines.name: English

lines.value: some species also rest on man made structures like piers jetties buoys and oil platforms
lines.name: English

lines.value: seals may move further inland and rest in sand dunes or vegetation and may even climb cliffs
lines.name: English

lines.value: most cetaceans live in the open ocean and species like the sperm whale may dive to depths of in search of food
lines.name: English

lines.value: sirenians live in shallow coastal waters usually living below sea level
lines.name: English

lines.value: however they have been known to dive to to forage deep water seagrasses
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea otters live in protected areas such as rocky shores kelp forests and barrier reefs although they may reside among drift ice or in sandy muddy or silty areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: many marine mammals seasonally migrate
lines.name: English

lines.value: annual ice contains areas of water that appear and disappear throughout the year as the weather changes and seals migrate in response to these changes
lines.name: English

lines.value: in turn polar bears must follow their prey
lines.name: English

lines.value: in hudson bay james bay and some other areas the ice melts completely each summer an event often referred to as ice floe breakup forcing polar bears to go onto land and wait through the months until the next freeze up
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the chukchi and beaufort seas polar bears retreat each summer to the ice further north that remains frozen year round
lines.name: English

lines.value: seals may also migrate to other environmental changes such as el nino and traveling seals may use various features of their environment to reach their destination including geomagnetic fields water and wind currents the position of the sun and moon and the taste and temperature of the water
lines.name: English

lines.value: baleen whales famously migrate very long distances into tropical waters to give birth and raise young possibly to prevent predation by killer whales
lines.name: English

lines.value: the gray whale has the longest recorded migration of any mammal with one traveling from the sea of okhotsk to the baja peninsula
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the winter manatees living at the northern end of their range migrate to warmer waters
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals have a number of physiological and anatomical features to overcome the unique challenges associated with aquatic living
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of these features are very species specific
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals have developed a number of features for efficient locomotion such as torpedo shaped bodies to reduce drag modified limbs for propulsion and steering tail flukes and dorsal fins for propulsion and balance
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals are adept at thermoregulation using dense fur or blubber circulatory adjustments counter-current heat exchangers torpedo shaped bodies reduced appendages and large size to prevent heat loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals are able to dive for long periods of time
lines.name: English

lines.value: both pinnipeds and cetaceans have large and complex blood vessel systems which serve to store oxygen to support deep diving
lines.name: English

lines.value: other important reservoirs include muscles blood and the spleen which all have the capacity to hold a high concentration of oxygen
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are also capable of bradycardia reduced heart rate and vasoconstriction shunting most of the oxygen to vital organs such as the brain and heart to allow extended diving times and cope with oxygen deprivation
lines.name: English

lines.value: if oxygen is depleted marine mammals can access substantial reservoirs of glycogen that support anaerobic glycolysis of the cells involved during conditions of systemic hypoxia associated with prolonged submersion
lines.name: English

lines.value: sound travels differently through water and therefore marine mammals have developed adaptations to ensure effective communication prey capture and predator detection
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most notable adaptation is the development of echolocation in whales and dolphins
lines.name: English

lines.value: toothed whales emit a focused beam of high frequency clicks in the direction that their head is pointing
lines.name: English

lines.value: sounds are generated by passing air from the bony nares through the phonic lips
lines.name: English

lines.value: these sounds are reflected by the dense concave bone of the cranium and an air sac at its base
lines.name: English

lines.value: the focused beam is modulated by a large fatty organ known as the melon
lines.name: English

lines.value: this acts like an acoustic lens because it is composed of lipids of differing densities
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals have evolved a wide variety of features for feeding which are mainly seen in their dentition
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the cheek teeth of pinnipeds and odontocetes are specifically adapted to capture fish and squid
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast baleen whales have evolved baleen plates to filter feed plankton and small fish from the water
lines.name: English

lines.value: polar bears otters and fur seals have fur one of the defining mammalian features that is long oily and waterproof in order to trap air to provide insulation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in contrast other marine mammals - such as whales dolphins porpoises manatees dugongs and walruses - have lost long fur in favor of a thick dense epidermis and a thickened fat layer blubber in response to hydrodynamic requirements
lines.name: English

lines.value: wading and bottom feeding animals such as manatees need to be heavier than water in order to keep contact with the floor or to stay submerged
lines.name: English

lines.value: surface living animals such as sea otters need the opposite and free swimming animals living in open waters such as dolphins need to be neutrally buoyant in order to be able to swim up and down the water column
lines.name: English

lines.value: typically thick and dense bone is found in bottom feeders and low bone density is associated with mammals living in deep water
lines.name: English

lines.value: some marine mammals such as polar bears and otters have retained four weight bearing limbs and can walk on land like fully terrestrial animals
lines.name: English

lines.value: all cetaceans are carnivorous and predatory
lines.name: English

lines.value: toothed whales mostly feed on fish and cephalopods followed by crustaceans and bivalves
lines.name: English

lines.value: some may forage with other kinds of animals such as other species of whales or certain species of pinnipeds
lines.name: English

lines.value: one common feeding method is herding where a pod squeezes a school of fish into a small volume known as a bait ball
lines.name: English

lines.value: individual members then take turns plowing through the ball feeding on the stunned fish
lines.name: English

lines.value: coralling is a method where dolphins chase fish into shallow water to catch them more easily
lines.name: English

lines.value: killer whales and bottlenose dolphins have also been known to drive their prey onto a beach to feed on it
lines.name: English

lines.value: other whales with a blunt snout and reduced dentition rely on suction feeding
lines.name: English

lines.value: though carnivorous they house gut flora similar to that of terrestrial herbivores probably a remnant of their herbivorous ancestry
lines.name: English

lines.value: baleen whales use their baleen plates to sieve plankton among others out of the water there are two types of methods lunge feeding and gulp feeding
lines.name: English

lines.value: lunge feeders expand the volume of their jaw to a volume bigger than the original volume of the whale itself by inflating their mouth
lines.name: English

lines.value: this causes grooves on their throat to expand increasing the amount of water the mouth can store
lines.name: English

lines.value: they ram a baitball at high speeds in order to feed but this is only energy effective when used against a large baitball
lines.name: English

lines.value: gulp feeders swim with an open mouth filling it with water and prey
lines.name: English

lines.value: prey must occur in sufficient numbers to trigger the whale's interest be within a certain size range so that the baleen plates can filter it and be slow enough so that it cannot escape
lines.name: English

lines.value: otters are the only marine animals that are capable of lifting and turning over rocks which they often do with their front paws when searching for prey
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sea otter may pluck snails and other organisms from kelp and dig deep into underwater mud for clams
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is the only marine mammal that catches fish with its forepaws rather than with its teeth
lines.name: English

lines.value: under each foreleg sea otters have a loose pouch of skin that extends across the chest which they use to store collected food to bring to the surface
lines.name: English

lines.value: this pouch also holds a rock that is used to break open shellfish and clams an example of tool use
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sea otters eat while floating on their backs using their forepaws to tear food apart and bring to their mouths
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine otters mainly feed on crustaceans and fish
lines.name: English

lines.value: pinnipeds mostly feed on fish and cephalopods followed by crustaceans and bivalves and then zooplankton and warm blooded prey like sea birds
lines.name: English

lines.value: most species are generalist feeders but a few are specialists
lines.name: English

lines.value: they typically hunt non schooling fish slow moving or immobile invertebrates or endothermic prey when in groups
lines.name: English

lines.value: solitary foraging species usually exploit coastal waters bays and rivers
lines.name: English

lines.value: when large schools of fish or squid are available pinnipeds hunt cooperatively in large groups locating and herding their prey
lines.name: English

lines.value: some species such as california and south american sea lions may forage with cetaceans and sea birds
lines.name: English

lines.value: the polar bear is the most carnivorous species of bear and its diet primarily consists of ringed pusa hispida and bearded erignathus barbatus seals
lines.name: English

lines.value: polar bears hunt primarily at the interface between ice water and air they only rarely catch seals on land or in open water
lines.name: English

lines.value: the polar bear's most common hunting method is still hunting the bear locates a seal breathing hole using its sense of smell and crouches nearby for a seal to appear
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the seal exhales the bear smells its breath reaches into the hole with a forepaw and drags it out onto the ice
lines.name: English

lines.value: the polar bear also hunts by stalking seals resting on the ice
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon spotting a seal it walks to within and then crouches
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the seal does not notice the bear creeps to within of the seal and then suddenly rushes to attack
lines.name: English

lines.value: a third hunting method is to raid the birth lairs that female seals create in the snow
lines.name: English

lines.value: they may also feed on fish
lines.name: English

lines.value: sirenians are referred to as sea cows because their diet consists mainly of sea grass
lines.name: English

lines.value: when eating they ingest the whole plant including the roots although when this is impossible they feed on just the leaves
lines.name: English

lines.value: a wide variety of seagrass has been found in dugong stomach contents and evidence exists they will eat algae when seagrass is scarce
lines.name: English

lines.value: west indian manatees eat up to 60 different species of plants as well as fish and small invertebrates to a lesser extent
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea otters are a classic example of a keystone species their presence affects the ecosystem more profoundly than their size and numbers would suggest
lines.name: English

lines.value: they keep the population of certain benthic sea floor herbivores particularly sea urchins in check
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea urchins graze on the lower stems of kelp causing the kelp to drift away and die
lines.name: English

lines.value: loss of the habitat and nutrients provided by kelp forests leads to profound cascade effects on the marine ecosystem
lines.name: English

lines.value: north pacific areas that do not have sea otters often turn into urchin barrens with abundant sea urchins and no kelp forest
lines.name: English

lines.value: reintroduction of sea otters to british columbia has led to a dramatic improvement in the health of coastal ecosystems and similar changes have been observed as sea otter populations recovered in the aleutian and commander islands and the big sur coast of california however some kelp forest ecosystems in california have also thrived without sea otters with sea urchin populations apparently controlled by other factors
lines.name: English

lines.value: the role of sea otters in maintaining kelp forests has been observed to be more important in areas of open coast than in more protected bays and estuaries
lines.name: English

lines.value: an apex predator affects prey population dynamics and defense tactics such as camouflage
lines.name: English

lines.value: the polar bear is the apex predator within its range
lines.name: English

lines.value: several animal species particularly arctic foxes vulpes lagopus and glaucous gulls larus hyperboreus routinely scavenge polar bear kills
lines.name: English

lines.value: the relationship between ringed seals and polar bears is so close that the abundance of ringed seals in some areas appears to regulate the density of polar bears while polar bear predation in turn regulates density and reproductive success of ringed seals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the evolutionary pressure of polar bear predation on seals probably accounts for some significant differences between arctic and antarctic seals
lines.name: English

lines.value: compared to the antarctic where there is no major surface predator arctic seals use more breathing holes per individual appear more restless when hauled out on the ice and rarely defecate on the ice
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fur of arctic pups is white presumably to provide camouflage from predators whereas antarctic pups all have dark fur
lines.name: English

lines.value: killer whales are apex predators throughout their global distribution and can have a profound effect on the behavior and population of prey species
lines.name: English

lines.value: their diet is very broad and they can feed on many vertebrates in the ocean including salmon rays sharks even white sharks large baleen whales and nearly 20 species of pinniped
lines.name: English

lines.value: the predation of whale calves may be responsible for annual whale migrations to calving grounds in more tropical waters where the population of killer whales is much lower than in polar waters
lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to whaling it is thought that great whales were a major food source however after their sharp decline killer whales have since expanded their diet leading to the decline of smaller marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: a decline in aleutian islands sea otter populations in the 1990s was controversially attributed by some scientists to killer whale predation although with no direct evidence
lines.name: English

lines.value: the decline of sea otters followed a decline in harbor seal and steller sea lion populations the killer whale's preferred prey which in turn may be substitutes for their original prey now reduced by industrial whaling
lines.name: English

lines.value: a 2010 study considered whales to be a positive influence to the productivity of ocean fisheries in what has been termed a whale pump
lines.name: English

lines.value: whales carry nutrients such as nitrogen from the depths back to the surface
lines.name: English

lines.value: this functions as an upward biological pump reversing an earlier presumption that whales accelerate the loss of nutrients to the bottom
lines.name: English

lines.value: this nitrogen input in the gulf of maine is more than the input of all rivers combined emptying into the gulf some each year
lines.name: English

lines.value: whales defecate at the ocean's surface their excrement is important for fisheries because it is rich in iron and nitrogen
lines.name: English

lines.value: the whale feces are liquid and instead of sinking they stay at the surface where phytoplankton feed off it
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon death whale carcasses fall to the deep ocean and provide a substantial habitat for marine life
lines.name: English

lines.value: evidence of whale falls in present day and fossil records shows that deep sea whale falls support a rich assemblage of creatures with a global diversity of 407 species comparable to other neritic biodiversity hotspots such as cold seeps and hydrothermal vents
lines.name: English

lines.value: deterioration of whale carcasses happens though a series of three stages
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially moving organisms such as sharks and hagfish scavenge soft tissue at a rapid rate over a period of months to as long as two years
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is followed by the colonization of bones and surrounding sediments which contain organic matter by enrichment opportunists such as crustaceans and polychaetes throughout a period of years
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally sulfophilic bacteria reduce the bones releasing hydrogen sulphide enabling the growth of chemoautotrophic organisms which in turn support other organisms such as mussels clams limpets and sea snails
lines.name: English

lines.value: this stage may last for decades and supports a rich assemblage of species averaging 185 species per site
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals were hunted by coastal aboriginal humans historically for food and other resources
lines.name: English

lines.value: these subsistence hunts still occur in canada greenland indonesia russia the united states and several nations in the caribbean
lines.name: English

lines.value: the effects of these are only localized as hunting efforts were on a relatively small scale
lines.name: English

lines.value: commercial hunting took this to a much greater scale and marine mammals were heavily exploited
lines.name: English

lines.value: this led to the extinction of the steller's sea cow along with subsistence hunting and the caribbean monk seal
lines.name: English

lines.value: today populations of species that were historically hunted such as blue whales balaenoptera musculus and the north pacific right whale eubalaena japonica are much lower than their pre whaling levels
lines.name: English

lines.value: because whales generally have slow growth rates are slow to reach sexual maturity and have a low reproductive output population recovery has been very slow
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of whales are still subject to direct hunting despite the 1986 moratorium ban on whaling set under the terms of the international whaling commission iwc
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are only two nations remaining which sanction commercial whaling norway where several hundred common minke whales are harvested each year and iceland where quotas of 150 fin whales and 100 minke whales per year are set
lines.name: English

lines.value: japan also harvests several hundred antarctic and north pacific minke whales each year ostensibly for scientific research in accordance with the moratorium
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the illegal trade of whale and dolphin meat is a significant market in japan and some countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most profitable furs in the fur trade were those of sea otters especially the northern sea otter which inhabited the coastal waters between the columbia river to the south and cook inlet to the north
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fur of the californian southern sea otter was less highly prized and thus less profitable
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the northern sea otter was hunted to local extinction maritime fur traders shifted to california until the southern sea otter was likewise nearly extinct
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british and american maritime fur traders took their furs to the chinese port of guangzhou canton where they worked within the established canton system
lines.name: English

lines.value: furs from russian america were mostly sold to china via the mongolian trading town of kyakhta which had been opened to russian trade by the 1727 treaty of kyakhta
lines.name: English

lines.value: commercial sealing was historically just as important as the whaling industry
lines.name: English

lines.value: exploited species included harp seals hooded seals caspian seals elephant seals walruses and all species of fur seal
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scale of seal harvesting decreased substantially after the 1960s after the canadian government reduced the length of the hunting season and implemented measures to protect adult females
lines.name: English

lines.value: several species that were commercially exploited have rebounded in numbers for example antarctic fur seals may be as numerous as they were prior to harvesting
lines.name: English

lines.value: the northern elephant seal was hunted to near extinction in the late 19th century with only a small population remaining on guadalupe island
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has since recolonized much of its historic range but has a population bottleneck
lines.name: English

lines.value: conversely the mediterranean monk seal was extirpated from much of its former range which stretched from the mediterranean to the black sea and northwest africa and only remains in the northeastern mediterranean and some parts of northwest africa
lines.name: English

lines.value: polar bears can be hunted for sport in canada with a special permit and accompaniment by a local guide
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be an important source of income for small communities as guided hunts bring in more income than selling the polar bear hide on markets
lines.name: English

lines.value: the united states russia norway greenland and canada allow subsistence hunting and canada distributes hunting permits to indigenous communities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the selling of these permits is a main source of income for many of these communities
lines.name: English

lines.value: their hides can be used for subsistence purposes kept as hunting trophies or can be bought in markets
lines.name: English

lines.value: by catch is the incidental capture of non target species in fisheries
lines.name: English

lines.value: fixed and drift gill nets cause the highest mortality levels for both cetaceans and pinnipeds however entanglements in long lines mid water trawls and both trap and pot lines are also common
lines.name: English

lines.value: tuna seines are particularly problematic for entanglement by dolphins
lines.name: English

lines.value: by catch affects all cetaceans both small and big in all habitat types
lines.name: English

lines.value: however smaller cetaceans and pinnipeds are most vulnerable as their size means that escape once they are entangled is highly unlikely and they frequently drown
lines.name: English

lines.value: while larger cetaceans are capable of dragging nets with them the nets sometimes remain tightly attached to the individual and can impede the animal from feeding sometimes leading to starvation
lines.name: English

lines.value: abandoned or lost nets and lines cause mortality through ingestion or entanglement
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals also get entangled in aquaculture nets however these are rare events and not prevalent enough to impact populations
lines.name: English

lines.value: vessel strikes cause death for a number of marine mammals especially whales
lines.name: English

lines.value: in particular fast commercial vessels such as container ships can cause major injuries or death when they collide with marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: collisions occur both with large commercial vessels and recreational boats and cause injury to whales or smaller cetaceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the critically endangered north atlantic right whale is particularly affected by vessel strikes
lines.name: English

lines.value: tourism boats designed for whale and dolphin watching can also negatively impact on marine mammals by interfering with their natural behavior
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fishery industry not only threatens marine mammals through by catch but also through competition for food
lines.name: English

lines.value: large scale fisheries have led to the depletion of fish stocks that are important prey species for marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: pinnipeds have been especially affected by the direct loss of food supplies and in some cases the harvesting of fish has led to food shortages or dietary deficiencies starvation of young and reduced recruitment into the population
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the fish stocks have been depleted the competition between marine mammals and fisheries has sometimes led to conflict
lines.name: English

lines.value: large scale culling of populations of marine mammals by commercial fishers has been initiated in a number of areas in order to protect fish stocks for human consumption
lines.name: English

lines.value: shellfish aquaculture takes up space so in effect creates competition for space
lines.name: English

lines.value: however there is little direct competition for aquaculture shellfish harvest
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the other hand marine mammals regularly take finfish from farms which creates significant problems for marine farmers
lines.name: English

lines.value: while there are usually legal mechanisms designed to deter marine mammals such as anti predator nets or harassment devices individuals are often illegally shot
lines.name: English

lines.value: habitat degradation is caused by a number of human activities
lines.name: English

lines.value: marine mammals that live in coastal environments are most likely to be affected by habitat degradation and loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: developments such as sewage marine outfalls moorings dredging blasting dumping port construction hydroelectric projects and aquaculture both degrade the environment and take up valuable habitat
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example extensive shellfish aquaculture takes up valuable space used by coastal marine mammals for important activities such as breeding foraging and resting
lines.name: English

lines.value: contaminants that are discharged into the marine environment accumulate in the bodies of marine mammals when they are stored unintentionally in their blubber along with energy
lines.name: English

lines.value: contaminants that are found in the tissues of marine mammals include heavy metals such as mercury and lead but also organochlorides and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example these can cause disruptive effects on endocrine systems impair the reproductive system and lower the immune system of individuals leading to a higher number of deaths
lines.name: English

lines.value: other pollutants such as oil plastic debris and sewage threaten the livelihood of marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: noise pollution from anthropogenic activities is another major concern for marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is a problem because underwater noise pollution interferes with the abilities of some marine mammals to communicate and locate both predators and prey
lines.name: English

lines.value: underwater explosions are used for a variety of purposes including military activities construction and oceanographic or geophysical research
lines.name: English

lines.value: they can cause injuries such as hemorrhaging of the lungs and contusion and ulceration of the gastrointestinal tract
lines.name: English

lines.value: underwater noise is generated from shipping the oil and gas industry research and military use of sonar and oceanographic acoustic experimentation
lines.name: English

lines.value: acoustic harassment devices and acoustic deterrent devices used by aquaculture facilities to scare away marine mammals emit loud and noxious underwater sounds
lines.name: English

lines.value: two changes to the global atmosphere due to anthropogenic activity threaten marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first is increases in ultraviolet radiation due to ozone depletion and this mainly affects the antarctic and other areas of the southern hemisphere
lines.name: English

lines.value: an increase in ultraviolet radiation has the capacity to decrease phytoplankton abundance which forms the basis of the food chain in the ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: the second effect of global climate change is global warming due to increased carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere
lines.name: English

lines.value: raised sea levels sea temperature and changed currents are expected to affect marine mammals by altering the distribution of important prey species and changing the suitability of breeding sites and migratory routes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the arctic food chain would be disrupted by the near extinction or migration of polar bears
lines.name: English

lines.value: arctic sea ice is the polar bear's habitat
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has been declining at a rate of 13% per decade because the temperature is rising at twice the rate of the rest of the world
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the year 2050 up to two thirds of the world's polar bears may vanish if the sea ice continues to melt at its current rate
lines.name: English

lines.value: the marine mammal protection act of 1972 mmpa was passed on october 21 1972 under president richard nixon to prevent the further depletion and possible extinction of marine mammal stocks
lines.name: English

lines.value: it prohibits the taking the act of hunting killing capture and or harassment of any marine mammal or the attempt at such of any marine mammal without a permit issued by the secretary
lines.name: English

lines.value: authority to manage the mmpa was divided between the secretary of the interior through the us fish and wildlife service service and the secretary of commerce which is delegated to the national oceanic and atmospheric administration noaa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the marine mammal commission mmc was established to review existing policies and make recommendations to the service and noaa to better implement the mmpa
lines.name: English

lines.value: the service is responsible for ensuring the protection of sea otters and marine otters walruses polar bears the three species of manatees and dugongs and noaa was given responsibility to conserve and manage pinnipeds excluding walruses and cetaceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1979 convention on the conservation of migratory species of wild animals cms is the only global organization that conserves a broad range of animals of which includes marine mammals
lines.name: English

lines.value: of the agreements made three of them deal with the conservation of marine mammals accobams ascobans and the wadden sea agreement
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1982 the united nations convention on the law of the sea losc adopted a pollution prevention approach to conservation which many other conventions at the time also adopted
lines.name: English

lines.value: the agreement on the conservation of cetaceans in the black sea mediterranean sea and contiguous atlantic area accobams founded in 1996 specifically protects cetaceans in the mediterranean area and maintains a favorable status a direct action against whaling
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are 23 member states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the agreement on the conservation of small cetaceans of the baltic and north seas ascobans was adopted alongside accobams to establish a special protection area for europe's increasingly threatened cetaceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: other anti whaling efforts include a ten year moratorium in 1986 by the iwc on all whaling and an environmental agreement a type of international law the international convention for the regulation of whaling which controlled commercial scientific and subsistence whaling
lines.name: English

lines.value: the agreement on the conservation of seals in the wadden sea enforced in 1991 prohibits the killing or harassment of seals in the wadden sea specifically targeting the harbor seal population
lines.name: English

lines.value: the 1973 agreement on the conservation of polar bears between canada denmark greenland norway svalbard the united states and the soviet union outlawed the unregulated hunting of polar bears from aircraft and icebreakers as well as protecting migration feeding and hibernation sites
lines.name: English

lines.value: various non governmental organizations participate in marine conservation activism wherein they draw attention to and aid in various problems in marine conservation such as pollution whaling bycatch and so forth
lines.name: English

lines.value: notable organizations include the greenpeace who focus on overfishing and whaling among other things and sea shepherd conservation society who are known for taking direct action tactics to expose illegal activity
lines.name: English

lines.value: for thousands of years indigenous peoples of the arctic have depended on whale meat
lines.name: English

lines.value: the meat is harvested from legal non commercial hunts that occur twice a year in the spring and autumn
lines.name: English

lines.value: the meat is stored and eaten throughout the winter
lines.name: English

lines.value: the skin and blubber muktuk taken from the bowhead beluga or narwhal is also valued and is eaten raw or cooked
lines.name: English

lines.value: whaling has also been practiced in the faroe islands in the north atlantic since about the time of the first norse settlements on the islands
lines.name: English

lines.value: around 1000 long finned pilot whales are still killed annually mainly during the summer
lines.name: English

lines.value: today dolphin meat is consumed in a small number of countries worldwide which include japan and peru where it is referred to as chancho marino or sea pork
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some parts of the world such as taiji japan and the faroe islands dolphins are traditionally considered food and are killed in harpoon or drive hunts
lines.name: English

lines.value: there have been human health concerns associated with the consumption of dolphin meat in japan after tests showed that dolphin meat contained high levels of methylmercury
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are no known cases of mercury poisoning as a result of consuming dolphin meat though the government continues to monitor people in areas where dolphin meat consumption is high
lines.name: English

lines.value: the japanese government recommends that children and pregnant women avoid eating dolphin meat on a regular basis
lines.name: English

lines.value: similar concerns exist with the consumption of dolphin meat in the faroe islands where prenatal exposure to methylmercury and pcbs primarily from the consumption of pilot whale meat has resulted in neuropsychological deficits amongst children
lines.name: English

lines.value: ringed seals were once the main food staple for the inuit
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are still an important food source for the people of nunavut and are also hunted and eaten in alaska
lines.name: English

lines.value: seal meat is an important source of food for residents of small coastal communities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the seal blubber is used to make seal oil which is marketed as a fish oil supplement
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2001 two percent of canada's raw seal oil was processed and sold in canadian health stores
lines.name: English

lines.value: ;cetaceans various species of dolphins are kept in captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: these small cetaceans are more often than not kept in theme parks and dolphinariums such as seaworld
lines.name: English

lines.value: bottlenose dolphins are the most common species of dolphin kept in dolphinariums as they are relatively easy to train and have a long lifespan in captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: hundreds of bottlenose dolphins live in captivity across the world though exact numbers are hard to determine
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dolphin smile makes them popular attractions as this is a welcoming facial expression in humans however the smile is due to a lack of facial muscles and subsequent lack of facial expressions
lines.name: English

lines.value: organizations such as world animal protection and the whale and dolphin conservation society campaign against the practice of keeping cetaceans particularly killer whales in captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: in captivity they often develop pathologies such as the dorsal fin collapse seen in 60 90% of male killer whales
lines.name: English

lines.value: captives have vastly reduced life expectancies on average only living into their 20s
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the wild females who survive infancy live 46 years on average and up to 70 80 years in rare cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: wild males who survive infancy live 31 years on average and up to 50 60 years
lines.name: English

lines.value: captivity usually bears little resemblance to wild habitat and captive whales social groups are foreign to those found in the wild
lines.name: English

lines.value: captive life is also stressful due the requirement to perform circus tricks that are not part of wild killer whale behavior as well as restricting pool size
lines.name: English

lines.value: wild killer whales may travel up to in a day and critics say the animals are too big and intelligent to be suitable for captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: captives occasionally act aggressively towards themselves their tankmates or humans which critics say is a result of stress
lines.name: English

lines.value: dolphins are often trained to do several anthropomorphic behaviors including waving and kissing behaviors wild dolphins would rarely do
lines.name: English

lines.value: ;pinnipeds the large size and playfulness of pinnipeds make them popular attractions
lines.name: English

lines.value: some exhibits have rocky backgrounds with artificial haul out sites and a pool while others have pens with small rocky elevated shelters where the animals can dive into their pools
lines.name: English

lines.value: more elaborate exhibits contain deep pools that can be viewed underwater with rock mimicking cement as haul out areas
lines.name: English

lines.value: the most common pinniped species kept in captivity is the california sea lion as it is abundant and easy to train
lines.name: English

lines.value: these animals are used to perform tricks and entertain visitors
lines.name: English

lines.value: other species popularly kept in captivity include the grey seal and harbor seal
lines.name: English

lines.value: larger animals like walruses and steller sea lions are much less common
lines.name: English

lines.value: pinnipeds are popular attractions because they are disneyfied and consequently people often anthropomorphize them with a curious funny or playful nature
lines.name: English

lines.value: some organizations such as the humane society of the united states and world animal protection object to keeping pinnipeds and other marine mammals in captivity
lines.name: English

lines.value: they state that the exhibits could not be large enough to house animals that have evolved to be migratory and a pool could never replace the size and biodiversity of the ocean
lines.name: English

lines.value: they also oppose using sea lions for entertainment claiming the tricks performed are exaggerated variations of their natural behaviors and distract the audience from the animal's unnatural environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: ;otter sea otters can do well in captivity and are featured in over 40 public aquariums and zoos
lines.name: English

lines.value: the seattle aquarium became the first institution to raise sea otters from conception to adulthood with the birth of tichuk in 1979 followed by three more pups in the early 1980s
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2007 a youtube video of two cute sea otters holding paws drew 1.5 million viewers in two weeks and had over 20 million views
lines.name: English

lines.value: filmed five years previously at the vancouver aquarium it was youtube's most popular animal video at the time although it has since been surpassed
lines.name: English

lines.value: otters are often viewed as having a happy family life but this is an anthropomorphism
lines.name: English

lines.value: ;sirenians the oldest manatee in captivity was snooty at the south florida museum's parker manatee aquarium in bradenton florida
lines.name: English

lines.value: born at the miami aquarium and tackle company on july 21 1948 snooty was one of the first recorded captive manatee births
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was raised entirely in captivity and died at the age of 69
lines.name: English

lines.value: manatees can also be viewed in a number of european zoos such as the tierpark in berlin the nuremberg zoo in zooparc de beauval in france and in the aquarium of genoa in italy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the river safari at singapore features seven of them
lines.name: English

lines.value: bottlenose dolphins and california sea lions were used in the united states navy marine mammal program nmmp to detect mines protect ships from enemy soldiers and recover objects
lines.name: English

lines.value: the navy has never trained attack dolphins as they would not be able to discern allied soldiers from enemy soldiers
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were five marine mammal teams each purposed for one of the three tasks mk4 dolphins mk5 sea lions mk6 dolphins and sea lions mk7 dolphins and mk8 dolphins mk is short for mark
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dolphin teams were trained to detect and mark mines either attached to the seafloor or floating in the water column because dolphins can use their echolocative abilities to detect mines
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sea lion team retrieved test equipment such as fake mines or bombs dropped from planes usually out of reach of divers who would have to make multiple dives
lines.name: English

lines.value: mk6 protects harbors and ships from enemy divers and was operational in the gulf war and vietnam war
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dolphins would swim up behind enemy divers and attach a buoy to their air tank so that they would float to the surface and alert nearby navy personnel
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea lions would hand cuff the enemy and try to outmaneuver their counter attacks
lines.name: English

lines.value: the use of marine mammals by the navy even in accordance with the navy's policy continues to meet opposition
lines.name: English

lines.value: the navy's policy says that only positive reinforcement is to be used while training the military dolphins and that they be cared for in accordance with accepted standards in animal care
lines.name: English

lines.value: the inevitable stresses involved in training are topics of controversy as their treatment is unlike the animals natural lifestyle especially towards their confined spaces when not training
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is also controversy over the use of muzzles and other inhibitors which prevent the dolphins from foraging for food while working
lines.name: English

lines.value: the navy states that this is to prevent them from ingesting harmful objects but conservation activists say this is done to reinforce the trainers control over the dolphins who hand out food rewards
lines.name: English

lines.value: the means of transportation is also an issue for conservation activists since they are hauled in dry carriers and switching tanks and introducing the dolphin to new dolphins is potentially dangerous as they are territorial
lines.name: English

lines.value: fergus county is a county in the us state of montana
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of the 2010 census the population was 11586
lines.name: English

lines.value: its county seat is lewistown
lines.name: English

lines.value: the county was founded in 1885 and named for james fergus a montana politician who was instrumental in creating the county or according to another source john fergus ).
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the us census bureau the county has a total area of 4350 sqmi of which 4340 sqmi is land and 11 sqmi 0.2% is water
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of the census of 2000 there were 11893 people 4860 households and 3197 families residing in the county
lines.name: English

lines.value: the population density was 3 people per square mile 1/km
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were 5558 housing units at an average density of 1 per square mile 0/km
lines.name: English

lines.value: the racial makeup of the county was 97.10% white 0.08% black or african american 1.18% native american 0.19% asian 0.29% from other races and 1.16% from two or more races
lines.name: English

lines.value: 0.81% of the population were hispanic or latino of any race
lines.name: English

lines.value: 24.5% were of german 13.5% american 13.0% norwegian 9.3% irish and 9.0% english ancestry
lines.name: English

lines.value: 97.1% spoke english 1.2% german and 1.1% spanish as their first language
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were 4860 households out of which 28.70% had children under the age of 18 living with them 56.10% were married couples living together 6.70% had a female householder with no husband present and 34.20% were non families
lines.name: English

lines.value: 30.50% of all households were made up of individuals and 13.90% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average household size was 2.33 and the average family size was 2.91
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the county the population was spread out with 24.50% under the age of 18 6.10% from 18 to 24 23.60% from 25 to 44 25.80% from 45 to 64 and 19.90% who were 65 years of age or older
lines.name: English
